newsitem.title: USA: Blue-chip stocks end lower; concern over strong dollar.
newsitem.headline: Blue-chip stocks end lower; concern over strong dollar.

text.p: Blue-chip stocks ended lower Friday on concern the strong dollar would hurt the overseas sales of corporate giants such as International Business Machines Corp. and Eastman Kodak Co.
Investors were also biding their time before a Federal Reserve meeting on Tuesday that could bring higher interest rates.
The Dow Jones industrial average closed 15.49 points lower at 6,804.79. For the week, it lost 130.67 points.
In the broader market, advancing issues led declines 1,241 to 1,154 on active volume of 534 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange.

Wall Streeters worried the strong dollar was eroding the profit picture of multinationals, and they focused on Eastman Kodak, which tumbled 9-1/4 to 79 and IBM, off 4-3/8 to 132-1/2, in consolidated trading.
Tobacco shares were also weak, extending their recent slide on the tobacco suit story. Philip Morris Cos. fell 4-3/8 to 111-1/2 and Loews Corp. slid 5-1/8 to 93-3/8.
Beyond the focus on a handful of stocks, however, activity was surprisingly muted given that the quarterly "triple witching" expiration of options, index options and index futures took place.
The quiet tone in the market highlighted a furious sell-off in Kodak, the NYSE's most active issue with more than 11 million shares changing hands.
Kodak warned its sales for the first two months of the year were flat vs. a year earlier, putting part of the blame on the dollar.
Two Wall Street brokerage houses trimmed their earnings estimates on IBM, again citing the dollar.
For some time, analysts have cautioned that multinationals would begin to suffer from the strong currency. With concrete evidence now emerging, they said the concerns could become more widespread.

"Often this starts with somebody signalling to the investment community that there may be a problem," said Hugh Johnson, chief investment officer at First Albany Corp. "Then, it starts to become less specific."
"A lot of companies tell us they have adequately hedged for currency swings, but when you see a sophisticated company like Kodak get hit, you start to wonder," he added.
Kodak's sharp fall dragged the Dow index to its fourth straight loss, a fall that widened the average's slump to 131 points for the week.
Technology stocks edged lower, despite holding to positive ground for most of the session.
Analysts continue to watch the tech stocks for signs of an end to their two-month retreat but warned any recovery would likely take a considerable period of time.

"When a group gets whacked like this and then starts to find a bottom, it doesn't typically come roaring back right away," said Larry Wachtel, an analyst at Prudential Securities. "There has to be a convalescent period."

Among special situations, generic drug maker IVAX Corp. fell 1-5/8 to 10-3/4 on the American Stock Exchange after drug wholesaler Bergen Brunswig Corp. called off their merger. Bergen Brunswig rose 1/8 to 31-5/8 on the NYSE.
Outback Steakhouse Inc. lost 4-5/8 to 19 on Nasdaq after warning its first-quarter earnings would not meet Wall Street estimates.

Columbia/HCA Healthcare Corp. slumped 2-3/4 to 38-1/2 on the NYSE as uncertainty mounted over a federal probe of the company's El Paso, Texas operations. Columbia said it has not been told of the allegations underlying the investigation.
The Nasdaq Composite index fell 5.19 points to 1,254.07.
The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks rose 1.45 to 784.10. The American Stock Exchange index was off 0.33 at 591.22.
The NYSE Composite index of all listed common stocks rose 1.02 to 412.80. The average share was up 11 cents.
The Wilshire Associates Equity Index -- the market value of NYSE, American and Nasdaq issues -- was 7,468.073, up 14.222 or 0.19 percent.
